Fales Library and Special Collections
Lindseth Collection of Alice in Wonderland Ephemera
Montgomery, Lall G.
MSS.368
67 Linear Feet in 27 record cartons, 18 manuscript boxes, 31 flat boxes, 3 shared oversize boxes, 6 oversize folders, 1 rolled storage tube, 1 box binder, and 3 unhoused art objects.
1900-2015 1930-1970 The Lindseth Collection of Alice in Wonderland Ephemera comprises toys, auction catalogs, games, housewares, dolls, posters, books, vinyl sound discs and art relating to Alice in Wonderland collected by Dr. Lall Montgomery. This collection documents Alice in Wonderland in American popular culture.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.
Arrangement
The Lindseth Collection of Alice in Wonderland Ephemera is organized by series and then by object. When applicable, certain items have the following information: Title, Description and Dimension.
Oversized items are located at the end of the finding aid.
Researchers should be aware that there is some overlap between contents of the series. Some material, such as clippings and calendars, can be found in multiple series of the collection.
The Collection is arranged into 9 Series:
Series I: Auction Catalogs
Series II: Housewares/Decorations
Series III: Games/Dolls/Toys/Puppets
Series V: Printed Ephemera
Series IV: Photographs/Slides
Series VII: Books/Magazines/Clippings/Newspapers
Series VIII: Art
Series IX: Media
Biographical Note
The bulk of the material was acquired by Dr. Lall Montgomery.
Dr. Lall G. Montgomery was born in Deloraine, Manitoba in July 1902. He took his premedical work at the University of Manitoba and graduated in Medicine from the Manitoba Medical College in 1929. After graduation he spent two years in the study of tuberculosis in the Manitoba Sanatorium at Ninette, Manitoba, and then spent three years as a Fellow in Pathology in the Mayo Foundation of the University of Minnesota at the May Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota. After completing this Fellowship, he became director of the Department of Pathology and the Pathology Laboratories of the Ball Memorial Hospital, in Muncie, Indiana where he became Senior Pathologist in the Pathology Department. Dr. Lall G. Montgomery was a Founding Fellow of the College of American Pathologists, and Delegate from the Section on Pathology and Physiology to American Medical Association, President of the American Society of Clinical Pathologists, an Associate Editor of the Journal of the Indiana State Medical Association, and was a member of the Advisory Board of Medical Specialties, representing the Federation of State Medical Boards of the United States.
The Lall G. Montgomery Papers (1929-1970) are housed at Alexander M. Bracken Library, at Ball State University in Muncie Indiana.
In an article published in the January 1965 magazine Doll Collector, Dr. Montgomery says: "It may be difficult to imagine how collecting dolls may have occurred to a collector of translations, but again this will not seems as surprising to a collector as to the non-initiated; in fact this is the usual way in which any collection will branch out into many diverse fields of interest and into many seemingly unrelated ways and by-ways, such as in my case, specially illustrated editions, special biding, parodies, games, pictures, cutouts, sheet music and phonographic recordings, to mention just a few and of course, dolls."
Legal title, copyright, and literary rights reside with Archives and Special Collections, Ball State University Libraries, Muncie, IN.
Scope and Contents
The Lindseth Collection of Alice in Wonderland Ephemera comprises toys, auction catalogs, games, housewares, dolls, posters, books, vinyl sound discs and art relating to Alice in Wonderland. Dr. Lall G. Montgomery's collection represents the wide variety of different ways Alice in Wonderland and Alice Through the Looking Glass have been interpreted in American popular culture.
Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Lindseth Collection of Alice in Wonderland Ephemera; MSS 368; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
Related Material at Fales Library and Special Collections
The Alfred C. Berol Collection of Lewis Carroll, MSS.057
Processing Information
Processing decisions made prior to 2021 were not recorded. In April 2021, conservators and archivists rehoused selected boxes in the collection in preparation for off-site storage. Items were housed in boxes by material composition rather than series arrangement.
Related Materials
Della Thomas collection (1913-2004) housed at the Edmon Low Library at Oklahoma State University
G. Edward Cassady, M.D. and Margaret Elizabeth Cassady, R.N. Lewis Carroll collection of ephemera, housed at the USC Libraries at the University of Southern California
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and are unavailable to researchers.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Jon Lindseth, 2015. The accession number associated with this gift is 2017.191.
Custodial History
Items in accession number 2017.191 were loaned by Jon Lindseth to the Grolier Club for an exhibit in fall 2015. The materials were then transferred to NYU in November 2015.

Contents include reproductions of: A photograph of Charles Lutwidge Dodgson as a young man, a picture-puzzle letter sent to a child-friend, around 1870, a Looking-Glass letter sent by Lewis Carroll to a child-friend in 1893, A photograph of Alice Liddell taken by Lewis Carroll, pages from the manuscript of Alice's Adventures Underground, the original version of Alice in Wonderland, copied out as a gift for Alice Liddell, preliminary sketches by Lewis Carroll for Alice's Adventure's Underground, the Alice Wheel, a picture wheel for you to make up illustrating versions and aspects of Alice and the Wonderland characters, a letter from Carroll to a friendly critic, 1892, concerning his tastes and attitudes, a proof rubbing from the block of one of Tenniel's illustrations with corrections by the artist, the Wonderland Postage-Stamp Case, a facsimile model of the postage-stamp case invented by Lewis Carroll in 1889, and more Lewis Carroll, an anthology of some of Lewis Carroll's less familiar verses and entertainments.Lewis Carroll Jackdaw No. 137[Undated]788

Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 9/26

Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 10/26
Description: Wood: If you dream that you are walking along in an extensive wood, it denotes that you will quickly fall in love and also that you will be often married.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 11/26[Undated]3811
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 11/26
Description: Caterpillar: You will soon witness some marvelous spiritual phenomena. Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 12/26[Undated]3812
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 12/26
Description: Nest: bird's nest; for a young woman, this dream foretells a change of abode.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 13/26[Undated]3813
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 13/26
Description: Frog: Neglect, lack of interest in your work, slovenliness in dress and in manner.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 14/26[Undated]3814
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 14/26
Description: Whistling: Gives prediction of a sensational fire, or storm within a week from now.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 15/26[Undated]3815
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 15/26
Description: Baby: To dream you had to take a baby, is a hint to fulfill the dream at your earliest possible convenience.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 16/26[Undated]3816
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 16/26
Description: Treacle: Beware of excessive heat.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 17/26[Undated]3817
Scope and Content
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 17/26
Description: Tea: To sip or drink tea, gives promise that you will yet secure the secret of long life, that you may live one hundred years or more.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 18/26[Undated]3818
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 18/26
Description: Procession: You shall be the gainer or guardian of property; you shall be the parent of a son who will be an illustrious warrior. He will cause pain, but will be a mighty noble.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 19/26[Undated]3819
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 19/26
Description: Club: To dream of a club, denotes short imprisonment which will bring you no disgrace. You will only save money.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 20/26[Undated]3820
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 20/26
Description: Game: To dream of playing ball denotes you will be seized for gambling.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 21/26[Undated]3821
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 21/26
Description: Reading: To dream of reading, denotes a pleasure trip on which you will get secret information about a plan which will yield you prosperity. Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 22/26[Undated]3822
Scope and Contents
Title: Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 21/26
Description: Shoes: Practical jokes and unwise, harsh criticism alienate your dearest friends from you.Alice Among the Fortune Tellers 23/26[Undated]3823
